title: uninitialized variable in loop gives incorrect error

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: E-needs-test
labels.description: Call for participation: writing correctness tests

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
An uninitialized variable in a loop gives a confusing borrow checker error.

Example : 
```rust
loop {
        let mut input;
        std::io::stdin().read_line(&mut input).unwrap();
}
```

Expected:
```
error[E0381]: borrow of possibly uninitialized variable: input
```

Actual:
```
error[E0382]: borrow of moved value: `input`
 --> src/main.rs:5:36
  |
4 |         let mut input;
  |             --------- move occurs because `input` has type `std::string::String`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
5 |         std::io::stdin().read_line(&mut input).unwrap();
  |                                    ^^^^^^^^^^ value borrowed here after move
6 | }
  | - value moved here, in previous iteration of loop
```


The move error is confusing because it implies the variable somehow got moved despite being declared right before it is used.
